SENT.plain: The mesenteric infarction is a rare but life threatening cause of acute abdomen
A 55-year-old woman was referred to the hospital because of acute mesenteric infarction and in the history claudication
In the absence of risk factors (atrial fibrillation, atherosclerosis, nicotin abusus) a postoperative work up was started to identify the cause of the arterial occlusions
A primary antiphospholipid-antibody syndrome was found
The patient is now receiving low-dose aspirin and anticoagulation therapy
The follow-up over now 14 months shows no further events
